statement: The research plan lacks clarity on how the learnable parameter α in the adaptation function f(N, d_ij) = -α·log₂N·d_ij is learned during training, and a detailed analysis is necessary to assess its impact.
The three-stage training scheme proposed for ICAM may make the results unfair to compare the performance with other existing baseline models that use simpler training approaches.

The research plan claims to use comprehensive information but the proposed adaptation function only uses node-to-node distances and scale information, which seems to contradict the claims of comprehensive information usage.
The design choices for both the adaptation function and the Adaptation Attention Free Module (AAFM) lack rigorous theoretical analysis.

While ICAM is presented as an instance-conditioned model, the evaluation datasets consist only of uniformly distributed nodes, and demonstrating performance on datasets with diverse distributions would make the 'instance-conditioned' claim more convincing.

It would be beneficial to evaluate the performance of the adaptation function when it is only used in AAFM, considering that there are already works on incorporating auxiliary information into compatibility calculation.

The novelty of the proposed instance-conditioned adaptation function is very limited, as previous works have already demonstrated that integrating node-to-node distances and instance scales into neural solvers can improve generalization performance on large-scale instances.
The proposed AAFM is a simple adaptation from previous method AFT, limiting the technical contribution.
